strain.translation[0].definitions[0].def: worry that is caused by having to deal with a problem or work too hard over a long period of time
strain.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: I couldn’t look after him anymore; the strain was too much for me.
Did you find the job a strain?
the stresses and strains of police life
The long working hours put a severe strain on employees.
I could see that she was beginning to crack under the strain.
The trial has been a terrible strain for both of us.
It’s quite a strain on me when he’s drinking heavily.
I know you’ve been under a lot of strain lately.
strain.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a difficulty or problem that is caused when a person, relationship, organization, or system has too much to do or too many problems to deal with
strain.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The flu epidemic has put a huge strain on the health service.
The party split under the strain.
The dry summer has further increased the strain on water resources.
The attack has led to strains in the relationship between the two countries.
strain.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a situation in which something is being pulled or pushed, or is holding weight, and so might break or become damaged
strain.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: These four posts take the strain of the whole structure.
Some of these exercises put too much strain on the back muscles.
The rope snapped under the strain.
The strain on the cables supporting the bridge is enormous.
strain.translation[0].definitions[3].def: an injury to a muscle or part of your body that is caused by using it too much
strain.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Long hours working at a computer can cause eye strain.
The goalkeeper is still out of action with a knee strain.
strain.translation[0].definitions[4].def: a type of animal, plant, or disease
strain.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: a new strain of the flu virus
strain.translation[0].definitions[5].def: a particular quality which people have, especially one that is passed from parents to children
strain.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: There’s a strain of madness in his family.
strain.translation[0].definitions[6].def: an amount of a feeling that you can see in the way someone speaks, writes, paints etc
strain.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: a strain of bitterness in Young’s later work
strain.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The country’s health system is under great strain.
The cost of these wars put an intolerable strain on the economy.
How much can you invest without putting any undue strain on your finances?
She has been suffering from considerable emotional strain.
This welfare program has eased the financial strain of raising children alone.
Living with my parents put quite a strain on our marriage.
They are worried that the court system might collapse under the strain.
You can do much to ease the strain of the situation for her.
Claudia could see that he was under considerable strain.
Holidays help people to cope with the stresses and strains of life.
strain.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to injure a muscle or part of your body by using it too much or making it work too hard
strain.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I’ve strained a muscle in my leg.
You’ll strain your eyes trying to read in this light.
strain.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to try very hard to do something using all your strength or ability
strain.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: I strained my ears, listening for any sound in the silence of the cave.
She was straining to keep her head above the water.
Bill choked and gasped, straining for air.
strain.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to separate solid things from a liquid by pouring the mixture through something with very small holes in it
strain.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to cause difficulties for something by making too much work or too many problems which it cannot deal with easily
strain.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The increased costs will certainly strain our finances.
The incident has strained relations between the two countries.
I felt that my patience was being strained to the limit.
strain.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to pull hard at something or push hard against something
strain.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: Buddy’s huge gut strained against the buttons on his shirt.
a dog straining at its lead
